skill.name: enact/formatter
skill.description: Formats and prettifies JSON with configurable indentation
skill.summary: Formats and prettifies JSON with configurable indentation
skill.author: EnactProtocol

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. The scanner misidentified markdown code fence backticks as Ruby shell execution and YAML field descriptions as cryptographic algorithms. The actual code uses only safe standard JSON methods (JSON.parse, JSON.stringify) with no external commands, network calls, or file system access.

content.value_statement: JSON data often arrives in a compact format that is difficult to read and debug. This skill formats JSON strings with configurable indentation to make data human-readable while maintaining validity.
actual_capabilities: Parses and formats JSON strings with configurable indentation
Validates JSON input and reports parsing errors
Supports custom indentation levels (spaces per level)
Returns structured output with validation status
Handles malformed JSON gracefully with error messages
limitations: Operates on JSON strings, not files or URLs
Does not modify JSON structure or data values
Only supports space-based indentation, not tabs
No streaming or batch processing of multiple JSON documents

use_cases.title: Format Configuration Files
use_cases.description: Transform compact JSON configuration into readable formatted output with consistent indentation for code reviews and debugging.

use_cases.title: Prepare API Responses
use_cases.description: Reformat API response JSON to make it easier to inspect, log, and include in documentation or reports.

use_cases.title: Debug Data Transformations
use_cases.description: Quickly format JSON data at various stages of a pipeline to verify structure and content during development.

prompt_templates.title: Format and Validate
Batch JSON Processing

best_practices: Use consistent indentation (2 or 4 spaces) for team readability
Validate JSON before formatting to catch syntax errors early
Match indentation to project conventions for clean diffs
anti_patterns: Assuming formatted output is also sorted or normalized
Using formatting to hide structural issues in the data

faq.question: What indentation options are supported?
faq.answer: This skill supports numeric indentation values (1, 2, 4, etc.). Each number represents spaces per indentation level.

faq.question: Does this skill modify my original JSON?
faq.answer: No. This skill works with JSON strings provided as input and returns formatted output. The original data is not modified.

faq.question: Can I format JSON files directly?
faq.answer: This skill operates on JSON strings. For files, first read the file content as a string, then format it.

faq.question: What happens if the JSON is invalid?
faq.answer: Invalid JSON returns a response with valid: false and an error message describing the parsing issue.

faq.question: Does formatting change the data values?
faq.answer: No. Formatting only changes whitespace. All keys, values, and types remain unchanged.

faq.question: What JSON features are supported?
faq.answer: Standard JSON is fully supported including nested objects, arrays, strings, numbers, booleans, and null values.
